questions.text: Which view will best assess the maxillary sinus for potential fractures?
questions.solution:
Waters' view is commonly used to assess the maxillary sinuses and the structures of the mid-face, often involved in facial trauma like Le Fort fractures.

 

PNS and Orbit X-Ray views:

Views

Position

X-ray & structure/disease used

Waters’ View (Option A)
  • Maxillary sinus
  • Partially frontal sinus

Caldwell’s View

(Option B)
  • Frontal sinus (mainly)
  • Ethmoid sinus

Lateral View

(Option C)
  • All sinuses visible
  • Mastoid antrum/air cells

Submentovertex View

(Option D)
  • Sphenoid sinus (from the base of skull)

Towne’s View (AP Axial)

Occipital bone fractures

Posterior cranial fossa pathologies

questions.text: Which of the following sinuses does NOT drain through the osteomeatal unit?
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal sinus drains into the superior meatus, not through the osteomeatal unit.

 

Osteomeatal Unit (OMU): Key structure in the middle meatus of the nasal cavity, serving as the drainage pathway for the frontal, anterior ethmoid, and maxillary sinuses. It is a crucial region because blockages here often lead to chronic or recurrent sinusitis.

 

Components of the Osteomeatal Unit:

  • Uncinate Process: A thin, curved bone that is part of the lateral nasal wall which serves as a boundary for the drainage pathways of the sinuses.
  • Semilunar Hiatus: A crescent-shaped groove located beneath the middle nasal turbinate.It is the primary drainage pathway for the frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses.
  • Ethmoidal Bulla: A prominent ethmoid air cell located just above the semilunar hiatus.It is the largest of the anterior ethmoid air cells and plays a role in sinus drainage.
  • Infundibulum: A funnel-shaped passage that connects the maxillary sinus to the semilunar hiatus.

questions.text: Following CT image is kept as a spotter in your final year exam viva. What is the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Marked cell located between floor of orbit and superior boundary of maxillary sinus is known as Haller cell - an example of anterior ethmoidal air cell.

 

Ethmoidal air cells:

Anterior Air cells:

Agger Nasi
  • Anterior most air cell of Ethmoid sinus
  • Site: Within the Lacrimal bone in the medial side of the Orbit
  • Relation: Anterolateral and inferior to the frontal recess

Haller cell
  • Infraorbital ethmoid air cell
  • Site: Present between floor of orbit and upper boundary of maxillary sinus

Bulla ethmoidalis
  • Most consistent and largest ethmoid air cell
  • Located just posterior to the Agger nasi

 

Posterior Air cells:

Onodi cell
  • Also known as spheno-ethmoidal air cell
  • Close proximity to Optic nerve and Internal carotid artery
  • Better appreciable on CT- axial view

 

Concha bullosa (Option A):

  • Pneumatization of middle turbinate
  • Most common deformity seen in nose, non-pathological
  • CT:


 

Pneumatized superior turbinate (Option C):

  • Occasionally the superior turbinate can undergo pneumatization
  • CT:

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with persistent nasal congestion, facial pain exacerbated by bending forward, thick yellow nasal discharge, and reduced olfaction for two weeks. CT imaging reveals abnormalities in the paranasal sinuses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient’s symptoms of nasal congestion, facial pain localized to the cheeks, thick yellowish nasal discharge, and the findings on CT imaging showing sinus mucosal thickening and frothy fluid appearnace indicate maxillary sinusitis.

 

Sinusitis: Inflammation of the mucosal lining of the paranasal sinuses, often associated with infection/allergy.

 

Types:

Acute Sinusitis:

Duration
  • Symptoms lasting less than 4 weeks

Radiology
  • CT: Frothy appearance due to presence of bubbles in fluid

Treatment
  • Most cases resolve spontaneously; symptomatic relief with nasal decongestants, saline nasal sprays, and analgesics.
  • Antibiotics if bacterial infection is suspected (typically after 7-10 days of symptoms).

Subacute sinusitis:

Symptoms lasting 4 to 12 weeks.

Chronic sinusitis:

Duration
  • Symptoms lasting longer than 12 weeks.

Radiology
  • CT: Bony sclerosis is seen and no air.

Treatment
  • Intranasal corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.
  • Saline irrigation.
  • Antibiotics for bacterial exacerbations.
  • Surgery (e.g., functional endoscopic sinus surgery) in refractory cases to improve drainage.

 

Complications of sinusitis:

  • Orbital cellulitis or abscess
  • Osteomyelitis of the skull
  • Meningitis
  • Intracranial abscess

 

Viral rhinitis (Option A): presents with clear nasal discharge and lacks significant mucosal thickening or air-fluid levels on imaging.

Allergic rhinitis (Option B): Allergic rhinitis is characterized by clear rhinorrhea, nasal itching, and sneezing, without purulent discharge or air-fluid levels.

Nasal polyps (Option D): Nasal polyps may cause nasal obstruction but are not typically associated with acute purulent discharge or air-fluid levels on imaging.

questions.text: The imaging below shows a double density sign in the paranasal sinuses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The double density sign on CT imaging of the paranasal sinuses is characteristic of allergic fungal sinusitis, indicating the presence of centrally hyperdense fungal material within the sinuses.

 

Allergic fungal sinusitis:

Etiopathogenesis
  • Allergic reaction to fungal organism (usually Aspergillus)

Clinical presentation
  • Age: 20-40 year females
  • B/L nasal polyposis: causing nasal obstruction
  • Characteristic peanut butter discharge: due to thick eosinophilic mucus

Bent & Kuhn criteria (used for Diagnosis)

Major criteria

Minor criteria
  • Type-I Hypersensitivity
  • Nasal polyposis
  • Characteristic CT findings
  • Eosinophilic mucin
  • Positive fungal stain
  • Asthma
  • Unilateral disease
  • Bone erosion (X-ray)
  • Serum eosinophilia
  • Positive fungal culture
  • Charcot-leyden crystals

Radiology

CT: Double density sign

questions.text: A 20-year old male, following a fist fight where he got hit over his front face presented with pain and swelling over his nose. A leak from the nasal cavity was noted, watery in consistency. What is the initial investigation of choice to localize the site of leak?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of nasal bone fracture (history of trauma to front) with CSF rhinorrhea (leak-watery in consistency).
  • Beta-2-transferrin assay (Option B): IOC for CSF Rhinorrhea
  • HRCT (Option C): Radiological IOC for localization of leak

 

CT Cisternography (can be combined with MR Cisternography) can be done when HRCT is inconclusive.

 

CSF Rhinorrhea:

  • Filter paper test: Double halo sign/ Target sign

  • Beta-2-transferrin assay: Confirms presence of CSF
  • Glucose estimation: around 60 mg/dL - suggests presence of CSF
  • Other laboratory tests: Beta-trace proteins, Intrathecal fluorescein test

 

  • HRCT:

 

  • CT Cisternography:



 

Nasal Bone fracture:

  • X-ray lateral view:

X-ray PNS (Option A): Though done commonly, is not an useful investigation for localizing the site of leak.

CT Angiography (Option D): Arteries are nowhere related to CSF Rhinorrhea and hence not used.

 

Learning objective:

Kero’s classification:

  • Radiological classification used to determine the height of Olfactory fossa based on the height of lateral lamella of cribriform plate (evaluated in CT).
  • Three categories:

Type-I

1-3 mm depth

Type-II

4-7 mm depth (most common type)

Type-III

≥ 8 mm depth (↑ risk of CSF rhinorrhea)

questions.text:
Daniel, a 60 year old male presented with complaints of nasal obstruction and epistaxis. MRI Head showed the following.

 



What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly male with unilateral obstruction with epistaxis and MRI showing cerebriform appearance arising from lateral wall of nose is suggestive of Inverted papilloma.

 

Inverted papilloma: (aka) [Transitional cell papilloma (or) Ringertz tumor]

Description
  • Tumor of non-olfactory mucosa of nose and paranasal sinus.

Radiology
  • Radiological IOC: MRI > CT - shows cerebriform appearance

(Option B)

 

Other options:

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Option A)

IOC: Contrast enhanced CT scan (CECT) shows Holman miller sign (also known as) Antral sign - anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus.

Esthesio- neuroblastoma (Option C)

IOC: MRI >> CT, ‘Figure of 8’ appearance with waist over cribriform plate is seen in MRI.

Antrochoanal polyp (Option D)

IOC: CECT - shows mass arising from maxillary sinus extending into the nasal cavity with widening of osteomeatal complex.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with right ear bleeding and conductive hearing loss (Rinne negative, Weber lateralized to right following head trauma.CT findings as shown as below.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Longitudinal temporal bone fractures, typically resulting from lateral head trauma, often present with ear bleeding and conductive hearing loss with CT image showing a fracture line along the long axis of the temporal bone is suggestive of Longitudinal fracture of Right temporal bone.
 

Temporal Bone fracture types:

 

Longitudinal fracture

Transverse fracture

Description

Fracture line across the/parallel to the long axis of the temporal bone.

Fracture line perpendicular to the long axis of temporal bone.

Incidence

More common

Less common

Mode of injury

Trauma to temporal/parietal region

Trauma to frontal/occipital region

Hemotympanum / TM rupture

Common

Rare

CSF Otorrhea

Common

Rare

Facial nerve damage

Rare

Common

Hearing loss

Conductive

Sensorineural

Injury to labyrinth/ VIII nerve

Rare

Common

Radiology (CT)

questions.text:
A 20-weeks primigravida complaints of severe headache, nausea and vomiting. MRI done showed the following.



Which of the following combinations of diagnosis and investigation of choice is most appropriate?

choices.text: Tortuous internal carotid artery; CT angiogram

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Sigmoid sinus thrombosis; MR venogram

 

Explanation:

  • A pregnant female with severe headache associated with nausea/vomiting with thrombosis present over sigmoid sinus and absent flow void (as seen in MRI) is diagnostic of Sigmoid Sinus thrombosis.MR venogram is the investigation of choice for diagnosing sigmoid sinus thrombosis, as it provides detailed visualization of venous structures and can accurately detect thrombi.

 

Sigmoid sinus thrombosis:

Risk factors

Females on OCPs, pregnancy.

Hypercoagulable states: Protein-C,S deficiency , Factor-V leiden mutation.

Complication of CSOM/Mastoditis

Trauma

Clinical features

Severe headache, nausea, vomiting

Radiology

CECT:

  • Non-opacification of sigmoid sinus
  • Empty delta sign: (seen with contrast)

NCCT:

  • Cord sign: Hyperdense vessel (attenuation) secondary to thrombosis
  • Delta sign: seen in CT without contrast (NCCT)

MRI (T2-weighted): Absent flow void with associated thrombosis seen

CE-MRI: Filling defect with thrombus seen (a-T1 ; b-T2 weighted image)

MR Venogram: Best investigation for localization

 

Tortuous internal carotid artery; CT angiogram(Option A): Tortuous ICA (Internal Carotid Artery) is not suggested by the MRI findings. CT angiogram is typically used to evaluate arterial abnormalities, not venous thrombosis.
 

Sigmoid sinus thrombosis; NCCT (Option B): While sigmoid sinus thrombosis is the correct diagnosis, Non-Contrast CT (NCCT) is less sensitive in detecting venous sinus thrombosis compared to MR venography.
 

Tortuous internal carotid artery; CECT (Option C):Tortuous ICA is not indicated by the MRI findings, and Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT) is more suited for arterial pathologies rather than venous thrombosis.

questions.text:
Following sign was seen while performing a radiological investigation



Identify the investigation and the corresponding diagnosis.

choices.text: Digital subtraction Angiography- Carotid body tumor

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Digital subtraction Angiography- Carotid body tumor

 

Explanation:

Investigation shown is Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) and Lyre sign is seen at the carotid bifurcation, which is suggestive of Carotid body tumor - a type of Paraganglioma.

 

Radiological findings in carotid body tumor:

NCCT

Large well defined mass seen over carotid bifurcation

CECT

Well defined peripherally enhancing lesion at carotid bifurcation

MRI (T2-weighted)

Mass splaying the carotid bifurcation is seen

MR Angiogram

Bilateral carotid body tumor seen

Digital subtraction Angiography (DSA)

Lyre sign positive (Option C)

 

MR Angiogram- Glomus jugulare (Option A): The image is clearly a Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) due to the sharp, flow-related contrast and bone subtraction, not an MRA. A Glomus jugulare tumor is located in the jugular foramen, superior to the carotid bifurcation shown here.

Digital subtraction Angiography-glomus jugulare (Option B): While the imaging modality is correctly identified as DSA, the location and "splaying" appearance are characteristic of a carotid body tumor, not a glomus jugulare, which arises from the jugular bulb.

MR Angiogram- Carotid body tumor (Option D): The diagnosis of a Carotid body tumor is consistent with the image findings, but the imaging modality depicted is a Digital Subtraction Angiography, not an MR Angiogram.

questions.text:
An elderly male presented with unilateral hearing loss associated with tinnitus came. Investigation done showed the following appearance.



What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Vestibular schwannoma (also known as) Acoustic neuroma.

 

Vestibular schwannoma:

Radiology
  • Investigation of choice/Gold standard: MRI with Gadolinium contrast - ice cream cone appearance seen on CP angle.
  • Other investigations:
    • CT (with/without contrast): done when MRI is not feasible
    • Vertebral Angiography: though helps in localizing the tumor, it is not the investigation of choice.

questions.text:
Young female with lower jaw swelling, X-ray showed the following.



What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Soap bubble appearance in the lower jaw is suggestive of Adamantinoma.

 

Adamantinoma:

  • Also known as ameloblastoma.
  • X-ray: soap bubble lesion (no matrix calcification)



 

Differential diagnoses for jaw lesions:

 

1) Pindborg tumor:

  • Calcifying epithelial odontogenic tumor.
  • More common in the premolar and molar region of the lower jaw.
  • Radiology:
    • X-ray: shows snow driven appearance.

  • CT: Radiolucent with scattered areas of calcification.
  • Confirmation of diagnosis is done by Biopsy (gold standard).

 

2) Sialolithiasis:

  • Calculi of the salivary gland ducts - submandibular gland is involved most commonly.
  • Radiology:
    • >80% of the stones are radiopaque, hence X-ray/CT is preferred over USG.

  • Sialography: useful in localizing the stone in the duct.

3) Ranula:

  • Mucous extravasation cyst secondary to obstruction of minor salivary glands.
  • Origin: Sublingual space - floor of mouth.
  • Can complicate into Plunging ranula (retention cyst).
  • Radiology: CT.

questions.text:
Match the following X-rays with the corresponding pathologies


	
		
			
			1)
			
			
			a) Coin in trachea
			
		
		
			
			2)
			
			
			b) Coin in esophagus
			
		
		
			 
			
			c) Button battery in esophagus
			
		
		
			 
			
			d) Button battery in trachea
questions.solution:
Coin in the esophagus is identified by a circular shaped opacity seen on AP view and appears slit-like on lateral view.

Coin in trachea: Slit-like on AP view and Circular opacity on lateral view.

Button battery:

  • Can get dislodged in the esophagus following accidental ingestion.
  • Peripheral double contour ring (or) Halo sign seen with step off on X-ray distinguishes button battery from coin in esophagus.

questions.text: The MRI images below display a "tram-track" sign, characterized by enhancement surrounding the optic nerve. This radiological feature is most indicative of which condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) ) Optic nerve sheath meningioma

 

Explanation:

Image is that of a FLAIR-MRI showing tram-track sign due to thickening of meninges, suggestive of Optic sheath meningioma (not Glioma) (Option C)

 

Optic sheath meningioma & Optic nerve glioma:

Optic nerve glioma

Optic sheath meningioma
  • Fusiform swelling of the optic nerve
    (option B ruled out)
  • Tram-track sign (thickening of meninges)
  • Associated with NF-1
  • Associated with NF-2

 

Optic neuritis (Option A): typically presents with diffuse enlargement and enhancement of the optic nerve itself due to inflammation.

Orbital pseudotumor (Option B) can involve various orbital structures and often presents with a more diffuse, infiltrative mass without the distinct "tram-track" enhancement pattern.

questions.text: A 30-year old female visited an Ophthalmology clinic with complaints of proptosis, difficulty in eye mobility and redness of eyes. Her TFT values were T3/T4-high, TSH-low. Which of the following structures shown in the right orbit is first to be affected first in her condition?
questions.solution:
First and most common muscles to be affected in Thyroid ophthalmoplegia are the recti in this order: Inferior rectus (3) > Medial rectus (2) > Superior rectus (1) > Lateral rectus (4).

CT image shows Right orbit with Extraocular muscles - enlarged Inferior and medial rectus is seen.

  • MRI: T1WI shows Coke bottle sign in the axial view

Differential diagnoses:

Thyroid eye disease

Pseudotumor of orbit

Tolosa hunt syndrome

Tendon is spared

Tendon is involved

Painful ophthalmoplegia with associated Sensory symptoms (Optic nerve/Trigeminal nerve +/- Cavernous sinus involvement)
